tit.cmt: このファイルの固有名詞は以下の宮内庁のホームページを参考にした。http://www.kunaicho.go.jp/esyouwa/esyouwa.htmlhttp://sankan.kunaicho.go.jp/english/index.htmlhttp://www.kunaicho.go.jp/e07/ed07-05.html

sen.j: 京都御所（きょうとごしょ）は、京都府京都市上京区にある皇居。
sen.e: Kyoto Gosho is an imperial palace located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kyoto Gosho is an imperial palace located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kyoto Gosho is an imperial palace located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 明治維新の東京行幸により、天皇が東京の皇居（旧江戸城）に移ったため、明治10年（1877年）保存された。
sen.e: Since the Emperor's visit to Tokyo in Meiji Restoration, the Emperor has resided in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo (the former Edo-jo Castle) and thus the Kyoto Gosho has been preserved since 1877.
sen.cmt: terms欄の江戸城をEdo-jo Castleに書き換え
sen.e: Since the Emperor's visit to Tokyo in Meiji Restoration, the Emperor has resided in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo (the former Edo-jo Castle) and thus the Kyoto Gosho has been preserved since 1877.
Since the Emperor's visit to Tokyo in Meiji Restoration, the Emperor has resided in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo (the former Edo-jo Castle) and thus the Kyoto Gosho has been preserved since 1877.

sen.j: 明治以降は京都皇宮（きょうとこうぐう）とも称される。
sen.e: Since the Meiji period, the Kyoto Gosho has also been called Kyoto Kogu.
Since the Meiji period, the Kyoto Gosho has also been called Kyoto Kogu.
Since the Meiji period, the Kyoto Gosho has also been called Kyoto Kogu.

sen.j: 元々平安京での正式な皇居は平安京の中央部付近に位置する内裏であったが、戦乱などによって荒廃したために里内裏に移った。
sen.e: Originally, the official imperial palace in Heiankyo was Dairi, situated nearby the center of Heiankyo, but after being devastated by wars, the imperial palace was moved to Satodairi (a temporary palace).

Originally, the official imperial palace in Heiankyo was Dairi, situated nearby the center of Heiankyo, but after being devastated by wars, the imperial palace was moved to Satodairi (a temporary palace).

Originally, the official imperial palace in Heiankyo was Dairi, situated nearby the center of Heiankyo, but after being devastated by wars, the imperial palace was moved to Satodairi (a temporary palace).

sen.j: 土御門東洞院内裏は、この里内裏の一つで、後に北朝と呼ばれる事になる持明院統の天皇家が歴代居住した御所であった。
sen.e: Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dairi, one of the temporary palaces, was the imperial palace in which successive imperial families of Jimyoin-to, later called North Imperial Court, resided.
Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dairi, one of the temporary palaces, was the imperial palace in which successive imperial families of Jimyoin-to, later called North Imperial Court, resided.
Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dairi, one of the temporary palaces, was the imperial palace in which successive imperial families of Jimyoin-to, later called North Imperial Court, resided.

sen.j: ちなみに南朝と呼ばれる事になる大覚寺統の天皇家の御所は二条富小路内裏であった。
sen.e: The imperial palace for imperial families of Daikakuji-to, later called South Imperial Court, was Nijo-Tominokoji Dairi.
The imperial palace for imperial families of Daikakuji-to, later called South Imperial Court, was Nijo-Tominokoji Dairi.
The imperial palace for imperial families of Daikakuji-to, later called South Imperial Court, was Nijo-Tominokoji Dairi.

sen.j: 現代の京都御所は土御門東洞院内裏そのものではなく、土御門東洞院内裏を基に拡充されたものである。
sen.e: The current Kyoto Gosho is not the original Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dairi itself, but was expanded based on it.
The current Kyoto Gosho is not the original Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dairi itself, but was expanded based on it.
The current Kyoto Gosho is not the original Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dairi itself, but was expanded based on it.

sen.j: 普段は申し込みする事で参観出来るほか、春と秋には一般公開される。
sen.e: The Kyoto Gosho is usually open to the visitors by application and to the public in Spring and Fall.
The Kyoto Gosho is usually open to the visitors by application and to the public in Spring and Fall.
The Kyoto Gosho is usually open to the visitors by application and to the public in Spring and Fall.

sen.j: 京都御所は、明治2年（1869年）の東京行幸まで歴代天皇の居所・執務所であった。
sen.e: The Kyoto Gosho was a residence and an office for the successive Emperors until the Emperor's visit to Tokyo in 1869.
The Kyoto Gosho was a residence and an office for the successive Emperors until the Emperor's visit to Tokyo in 1869.
The Kyoto Gosho was a residence and an office for the successive Emperors until the Emperor's visit to Tokyo in 1869.

sen.j: 現在（21世紀）の京都御所は国有財産で、宮内庁が管轄する「皇室用財産」に分類されている。
sen.e: The existing (the 21st century) Kyoto Gosho is a national property and classified as "Properties for Imperial Household Use" under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.
The existing (the 21st century) Kyoto Gosho is a national property and classified as "Properties for Imperial Household Use" under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.
The existing (the 21st century) Kyoto Gosho is a national property and classified as "Properties for Imperial Household Use" under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.

sen.j: 隣接して京都大宮御所、仙洞御所があり、また北隣の今出川通を挟んで同志社大学と同志社女子大学（両校とも今出川キャンパス）が位置する。
sen.e: Adjacent to the Kyoto Gosho lie Kyoto Omiya Gosho and Sento Gosho, and to the north, across Imadegawa-dori lie Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (both Imadegawa Campus).
sen.cmt: terms欄の御所Imperial Palaceを削除し、Goshoに書き換え。
sen.e: Adjacent to the Kyoto Gosho lie Kyoto Omiya Gosho and Sento Gosho, and to the north, across Imadegawa-dori lie Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (both Imadegawa Campus).

Adjacent to the Kyoto Gosho lie Kyoto Omiya Gosho and Sento Gosho, and to the north, across Imadegawa-dori lie Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (both Imadegawa Campus).

sen.j: 現在は京都御所、京都大宮御所と仙洞御所を宮内庁が管理し、その周囲の国民公園である京都御苑を環境省が管理している。
sen.e: Today, the Kyoto Gosho, the Kyoto Omiya Gosho, and the Sento Gosho are maintained by the Imperial Household Agency, and Kyoto Gyoen, which is the national park around the imperial palaces, is maintained by the Ministry of Environment.
sen.cmt: terms欄の京都御苑についてNational Gardenを削除。
sen.e: Today, the Kyoto Gosho, the Kyoto Omiya Gosho, and the Sento Gosho are maintained by the Imperial Household Agency, and Kyoto Gyoen, which is the national park around the imperial palaces, is maintained by the Ministry of Environment.

Today, the Kyoto Gosho, the Kyoto Omiya Gosho, and the Sento Gosho are maintained by the Imperial Household Agency, and Kyoto Gyoen, which is the national park around the imperial palaces, is maintained by the Ministry of Environment.

sen.j: 京都市民は京都御苑も含めて、単に「御所」（ごしょ）と呼ぶ事が多い。
sen.e: Usually, the citizens of Kyoto refer to the Kyoto Gosho including the Kyoto Gyoen simply as "Gosho."
Usually, the citizens of Kyoto refer to the Kyoto Gosho including the Kyoto Gyoen simply as "Gosho."
Usually, the citizens of Kyoto refer to the Kyoto Gosho including the Kyoto Gyoen simply as "Gosho."

sen.j: なお、海外のお城とは違い、御所を覆う塀はあまり高くはないが、これは東洋と西洋での支配者（天皇やなど皇族）に対する庶民の親近感の違いが現れているという考察がある。
sen.e: Apart from castles in foreign countries, walls surrounding the Gosho are not very high, which is viewed as a difference in people's feeling (e.g., familiarity) against rulers (imperial family including the Emperor) of the East and the West.

Unlike castles in foreign countries, walls surrounding the Gosho are not very high, which is viewed as the difference in how the people of the East and the West feel toward their rulers (Imperial Family and the Emperor).

Unlike castles in foreign countries, walls surrounding the Gosho are not very high, which is viewed as the difference in how the people of the East and the West feel toward their rulers (Imperial Family and the Emperor).

sen.j: 例えば、フランス革命の際、支配者（王）の居城であったベルサイユ宮殿に庶民が侵入するという出来事があったような事例が、日本では発生していないのがこうした考察の根拠の１つである。
sen.e: This consideration is based on the example of the French Revolution, in which the crowd broke into the Palace of Versailles, the palace of the ruler (king), whereas such an event has not occurred in Japan.

This consideration is based on the example of the French Revolution in which the crowd broke into the Palace of Versailles, which was the palace of the ruler (king), whereas such an event has not occurred in Japan.

This consideration is based on the example of the French Revolution in which the crowd broke into the Palace of Versailles, which was the palace of the ruler (king), whereas such an event has not occurred in Japan.

sen.j: 平安京建都当初の内裏は現在の京都御所よりかなり西方にあり、西日本旅客鉄道二条駅の近くの千本丸太町交差点北東の位置にあった。
sen.e: The original Dairi (the imperial palace) in Heiankyo was located to the west of and far from the current Kyoto Gosho, at the northeast of the intersection at Senbon Maruta-machi nearby the Nijo Station of West Japan Railway Company.

The original Dairi (the imperial palace) in Heiankyo was located to the west of and far from the current Kyoto Gosho, at the northeast of the intersection at Senbon Maruta-machi nearby the Nijo Station of West Japan Railway Company.

The original Dairi (the imperial palace) in Heiankyo was located to the west of and far from the current Kyoto Gosho, at the northeast of the intersection at Senbon Maruta-machi nearby the Nijo Station of West Japan Railway Company.

sen.j: 現存の京都御所はもとは里内裏の一つで、土御門東洞院殿（つちみかどひがしのとういんどの）と言い、元弘元年（1331年）、北朝_(日本)の光厳天皇が最初に使用したものである。
sen.e: The existing Kyoto Gosho was originally one of the temporary palaces and called Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dono, which was initially used by the Emperor Kogon of the North Imperial Court (Japan) in 1331.

The existing Kyoto Gosho was originally one of the temporary palaces and called Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dono, which was initially used by the Emperor Kogon of the North Imperial Court (Japan) in 1331.

The existing Kyoto Gosho was originally one of the temporary palaces and called Tsuchimikado-Higashinotoin Dono, which was initially used by the Emperor Kogon of the North Imperial Court (Japan) in 1331.

sen.j: ここにあった内裏は江戸時代だけで8回再建されており（うち6回は火災焼失による再建）、現存する建物は江戸末期の安政2年（1855年）、平安様式にならって再建されたもので安政内裏と呼ばれるものである。
sen.e: During the Edo period, the Dairi was reconstructed eight times (six of them were caused by destruction by fire), and the existing building is called Ansei Dairi, which was reconstructed in accordance with the Heian style in 1855.

During the Edo period, the Dairi was reconstructed eight times (six of them were caused by destruction by fire), and the existing building is called Ansei Dairi, which was reconstructed in accordance with the Heian style in 1855.

During the Edo period, the Dairi was reconstructed eight times (six of them were caused by destruction by fire), and the existing building is called Ansei Dairi, which was reconstructed in accordance with the Heian style in 1855.

sen.j: 明治10年（1877年）、東京の皇居に移っていた明治天皇が京都を訪れた際、東京行幸後10年もたたないうちに荒廃が進んでいた京都御所の様子を嘆き、御所を保存し旧観を維持するように命じた。
sen.e: The Emperor Meiji, who had resided in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo for nearly ten years after his visit to Tokyo, visited Kyoto in 1877 and regretted to find the Kyoto Gosho being devastated and thus ordered the preservation of the Kyoto Gosho to maintain its original scenery.

Emperor Meiji, who had been living in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo for nearly ten years after his visit to Tokyo, visited Kyoto in 1877 and regretted to find the Kyoto Gosho being devastated; he ordered the preservation of the Kyoto Gosho to maintain its original scenery.

Emperor Meiji, who had been living in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo for nearly ten years after his visit to Tokyo, visited Kyoto in 1877 and regretted to find the Kyoto Gosho being devastated; he ordered the preservation of the Kyoto Gosho to maintain its original scenery.

sen.j: 主な建物としては、紫宸殿（ししんでん）、清涼殿、小御所（こごしょ）、御学問所、常御殿（つねごてん）、迎春（こうしゅん）、御涼所（おすずみしょ）、皇后御殿などがある。
sen.e: The main buildings in Kyoto Gosho inclulde Shishinden (Ceremonial Hall), Seiryoden, Kogosho, Gogakumonjo, Tsunegoten, Koshun, Osuzumisho, and Kogo Goten.
The main buildings in Kyoto Gosho inclulde Shishinden (Ceremonial Hall), Seiryoden, Kogosho, Gogakumonjo, Tsunegoten, Koshun, Osuzumisho, and Kogo Goten.
The main buildings in Kyoto Gosho inclulde Shishinden (Ceremonial Hall), Seiryoden, Kogosho, Gogakumonjo, Tsunegoten, Koshun, Osuzumisho, and Kogo Goten.

tit.cmt: 即位の礼、宮内庁の以下のサイトを参照http://www.kunaicho.go.jp/esyouwa/esyouwa.html

sen.j: 即位の礼は代々京都御所の紫宸殿で行なわれ、明治維新の際に天皇が東京へ移ってからも、明治22年（1889年）制定の旧皇室典範により、即位の礼と大嘗祭は京都で行なうと定められ、大正天皇と昭和天皇も京都御所で即位の儀式を行った。
sen.e: For generations, Ceremonies of Enthronement were held at Shishinden in Kyoto Gosho, and even after the Emperor moved to Tokyo in Meiji Restoration, under the former Imperial House Code as established in 1889 it was prescribed that the Ceremonies of Enthronement and Daijosai (the Great Thanksgiving Festival) should be held in Kyoto, thereby having the Ceremonies of Enthronement of the Emperor Taisho and the Emperor Showa in the Kyoto Gosho.
sen.cmt: terms欄のformer Koshitsu Tempan を削除。大嘗祭the Great Thanksgiving Festivalを追加。
sen.e: For generations, Ceremonies of Enthronement were held at Shishinden in Kyoto Gosho, and even after the Emperor moved to Tokyo in Meiji Restoration, under the former Imperial House Code as established in 1889 it was prescribed that the Ceremonies of Enthronement and Daijosai (the Great Thanksgiving Festival) should be held in Kyoto, thereby having the Ceremonies of Enthronement of the Emperor Taisho and the Emperor Showa in the Kyoto Gosho.

For generations, Ceremonies of Enthronement were held at Shishinden in Kyoto Gosho, and even after the Emperor moved to Tokyo in Meiji Restoration, under the former Imperial House Code as established in 1889 it was prescribed that the Ceremonies of Enthronement and Daijosai (the Great Thanksgiving Festival) should be held in Kyoto, thereby having the Ceremonies of Enthronement of the Emperor Taisho and the Emperor Showa in the Kyoto Gosho.

sen.j: また、第二次世界大戦後制定された現在の皇室典範では京都で行うというような場所の規定は特になく、平成2年（1990年）今上天皇の即位にあたり、史上初めて即位の礼が東京の皇居正殿で行われた。
sen.e: The present Imperial House Code as established after the World War II nowhere prescribes the place (e.g., Kyoto) for Ceremonies of Enthronement, and in 1990 for the first time in history, the Ceremony of Enthronement of the current Emperor was held at Seiden in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.
sen.cmt: terms欄のKoshitsu Tempanを削除。正殿Main Buildingを削除
sen.e: The present Imperial House Code as established after the World War II does not prescribe the place (e.g., Kyoto) for Ceremonies of Enthronement, and in 1990 for the first time in history, the Ceremony of Enthronement of the current Emperor was held at Seiden in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

The present Imperial House Code as established after the World War II does not prescribe the place (e.g., Kyoto) for Ceremonies of Enthronement, and in 1990 for the first time in history, the Ceremony of Enthronement of the current Emperor was held at Seiden in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

sen.j: 即位の際に天皇が着座し、その即位が象徴的に示される天皇の正式な御座所である高御座は京都御所の紫宸殿にあるため、今上天皇の即位の礼「正殿の儀」（「紫宸殿の儀」に相当）に際しては皇居宮殿に一時移設された。
sen.e: Takamikura, a formal impeiral chamber in which an Emperor will seat himself to thereby symbolically represent his Imperial Throne, is situated in Shishinden in Kyoto Gosho, and thus, at the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement "Seiden no Gi" for the current Emperor (corresponding to "Shishinden no Gi"), the Takamikura was temporarily relocated to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

Takamikura, a formal imperial chamber used at the enthronement ceremony in which an Emperor seats himself to symbolically represent his Imperial Throne, is located in Shishinden in Kyoto Gosho, and thus, at the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement "Seiden no Gi" for the current Emperor (corresponding to "Shishinden no Gi") the Takamikura was temporarily relocated to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

Takamikura, a formal imperial chamber used at the enthronement ceremony in which an Emperor seats himself to symbolically represent his Imperial Throne, is located in Shishinden in Kyoto Gosho, and thus, at the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement "Seiden no Gi" for the current Emperor (corresponding to "Shishinden no Gi") the Takamikura was temporarily relocated to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

sen.j: 御所正面入口の正門。
sen.e: The main gate on the front entrance of the Gosho.
The main gate on the front entrance of the Gosho.
The main gate on the front entrance of the Gosho.

sen.j: 素木、切妻造、桧皮葺（ひわだぶき）、柱間1間の四脚門である。
sen.e: The Gate is made of unpainted natural wood with a Kiritsuma zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof and is supported by four pillars having a distance of 1.82 meters therebetween.
sen.cmt: terms欄の柱間intercolumniationを削除。四脚門Shikyaku-mon Gate / Yotsuashi-mon Gate / gate with four pillarsを削除。1間＝1.82mとした。
sen.e: The Gate is made of unpainted natural wood with a Kiritsuma zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof and is supported by four pillars that are 1.82 meters apart.
sen.cmt: 四脚門の読み方は二通りある。"having a distance of 1.82 meters therebetween" simplified
sen.e: The Gate is made of unpainted natural wood with a Kiritsuma zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof and is supported by four pillars that are 1.82 meters apart.

sen.j: 開門されるのは天皇や要人国賓の来場や一般公開など、特別な行事の時のみである。
sen.e: The Gate would be open only on special events such as welcoming the Emperor and a foreign dignitary or the opening to the public.
The Gate is opened only for special events such as welcoming of the Emperor and foreign dignitaries as well as on the limited days for public viewing.
sen.cmt: Last part of the sentence modified.
sen.e: The Gate is opened only for special events such as welcoming of the Emperor and foreign dignitaries as well as on the limited days for public viewing.

sen.j: 左右の築地塀（ついじべい）には5本の筋（水平の線）が入っているが、これも塀として最高の格式を示すものである。
sen.e: Tsuiji-bei Walls on the left and right sides have five lines (horizontal lines), which represent the highest status as a wall.
Tsuiji-bei Walls on the left and right sides have five lines (horizontal lines), which represent the highest status as a wall.
Tsuiji-bei Walls on the left and right sides have five lines (horizontal lines), which represent the highest status as a wall.

sen.j: この門を入り、丹塗り瓦葺の承明門（じょうめいもん）をくぐると正面が紫宸殿である。
sen.e: Past this Gate is the Jomei-mon Gate with a Ninuri kawara roof, leading to Shishinden on the front.
Past this Gate is the Jomei-mon Gate with a Ninuri kawara roof, leading to Shishinden on the front.
Past this Gate is the Jomei-mon Gate with a Ninuri kawara roof, leading to Shishinden on the front.

sen.j: 右に見えるのは左近の桜
sen.e: On the right is Sakon no Sakura (a cherry tree).
On the right is Sakon no Sakura (a cherry tree).
On the right is Sakon no Sakura (a cherry tree).

sen.j: 御所の正殿で、天皇の即位式、立太子礼などの最重要儀式が執り行われた最も格式の高い建物である。
sen.e: The Shishinden is the main building with the highest status in the Gosho, where the most important ceremonies such as Ceremony of Enthronement of the Emperor and Rittaishi no Rei (Ceremony of Investiture) were conducted.

The Shishinden is the main building with the highest status in the Gosho, where the most important ceremonies such as Ceremony of Enthronement of the Emperor and Rittaishi no Rei (Ceremony of Investiture) were conducted.

The Shishinden is the main building with the highest status in the Gosho, where the most important ceremonies such as Ceremony of Enthronement of the Emperor and Rittaishi no Rei (Ceremony of Investiture) were conducted.

sen.j: 白砂の南庭（なんてい、だんてい）に面して南向きに建つ。
sen.e: The Shishinden faces toward the south, facing Dan-tei (Courtyard) with white sand.
The Shishinden faces toward the south, facing Dan-tei (Courtyard) with white sand.
The Shishinden faces toward the south, facing Dan-tei (Courtyard) with white sand.

sen.j: 入母屋造、桧皮葺の高床式宮殿建築の建物で、平面は33メートル×23メートルほどの規模がある。
sen.e: The Shishinden is the Takayuka style imperial architecture with a Irimoya zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof, and is 33 by 23 meters in size.
The Shishinden is the Takayuka style imperial architecture with an Irimoya zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof, and is 33 by 23 meters in dimension.
The Shishinden is the Takayuka style imperial architecture with an Irimoya zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof, and is 33 by 23 meters in dimension.

sen.j: 建具は蔀戸（しとみど）が使われている。
sen.e: Latticed shutters are used as door fittings.
sen.cmt: terms欄の建具tateguを削除。door fittingsに書き換え。蔀戸Shitomi-do Doorを削除。latticed shutters に書き換え。
sen.e: Latticed shutters are used as door fittings.
Latticed shutters are used as door fittings.

sen.j: 規模は大きいが、華美な装飾のない、簡素な建物である。
sen.e: Though the size of the building is large, the Shishinden is simple and less decorative.
Though the size of the building is large, the Shishinden is simple and less decorative.
Though the size of the building is large, the Shishinden is simple and less decorative.

sen.j: 構造は中央の母屋の東西南北に庇を付した形になる。
sen.e: The Shishinden has Moya (an enclosed main room) in the center and a hisashi (an unenclosed veranda) to the north, south, east and west of the Moya.
The Shishinden has Moya (an enclosed main room) in the center and a hisashi (an unenclosed veranda) to the north, south, east and west of the Moya.
The Shishinden has Moya (an enclosed main room) in the center and a hisashi (an unenclosed veranda) to the north, south, east and west of the Moya.

sen.j: 内部は板敷きの広い空間となり、中央に高御座（たかみくら、天皇の座）、その東に帳台（みちょうだい、皇后の座）が置かれている。
sen.e: Inside the Shishinden is a wide space of a wooden floor and lies the Takamikura (Throne for the Emperor) in the center and Michodai (Throne for the Empress) to the east.
There is a wide space with a wooden floor inside the Shishinden with the Takamikura (Throne for the Emperor) in the center and Michodai (Throne for the Empress) to its east.
There is a wide space with a wooden floor inside the Shishinden with the Takamikura (Throne for the Emperor) in the center and Michodai (Throne for the Empress) to its east.

sen.j: 高御座、御帳台ともに高さ約5メートル、平面八角形で、柱と柱の間に帳（とばり、カーテン）をめぐらし、内部には椅子が置かれている。
sen.e: Both the Takamikura and the Michodai are formed octagonal and about 5 meters above the floor, while tobari (a curtain) is provided between pillars and a chair inside.
Both the Takamikura and the Michodai are octagonal in shape and about 5 meters above the floor with a chair inside and tobari (a curtain) between pillars.
Both the Takamikura and the Michodai are octagonal in shape and about 5 meters above the floor with a chair inside and tobari (a curtain) between pillars.

sen.j: 高御座、御帳台の背後の襖は「賢聖障子」（けんじょうのしょうじ）と呼ばれ、中国古代の賢人32人の肖像が描かれている。
sen.e: In the back of the Takamikura and the Michodai lies fusuma (a sliding door) called Kenjo no Shoji, on which an image of 32 ancient Chinese sages is painted.
sen.cmt: terms欄の/ sliding screens of the thirty-two Chinese sagesを削除
sen.e: In the back of the Takamikura and the Michodai lies fusuma (a sliding door) called Kenjo no Shoji, on which images of 32 ancient Chinese sages are painted.
In the back of the Takamikura and the Michodai lies fusuma (a sliding door) called Kenjo no Shoji, on which images of 32 ancient Chinese sages are painted.

sen.j: これは平安時代からの伝統的な画題である。
sen.e: This has been the traditional subject matter since the Heian period.
This has been the traditional subject of paintings since the Heian Period.
This has been the traditional subject of paintings since the Heian Period.

sen.j: 現在の高御座と御帳台は、大正天皇の即位礼に際し、古制に則って造られたものである。
sen.e: The current Takamikura and Michodai were built at the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement of the Taisho Emperor, conforming to the old rule.
The current Takamikura and Michodai were built at the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement of the Taisho Emperor, conforming to the old rule.
The current Takamikura and Michodai were built at the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement of the Taisho Emperor, conforming to the old rule.

sen.j: 今上陛下の即位礼の際には、一度解体した後、東京の宮殿に運ばれて使用された。
sen.e: At the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement of the current Emperor, they were once broken apart and then transferred to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo to be used.
At the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement of the current Emperor, they were taken apart once and then transferred to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo to be used.
At the time of the Ceremony of Enthronement of the current Emperor, they were taken apart once and then transferred to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo to be used.

sen.j: 建物正面の階段の左右には「左近桜」と「右近橘」の木がある。
sen.e: On either side of the Shishinden's main stairway lie trees, Sakon no Sakura (a cherry tree) on the left and Ukon no Tachibana (a mandarin orange tree) on the right.
On either side of the Shishinden's main stairway lie trees, Sakon no Sakura (a cherry tree) on the left and Ukon no Tachibana (a mandarin orange tree) on the right.
On either side of the Shishinden's main stairway lie trees, Sakon no Sakura (a cherry tree) on the left and Ukon no Tachibana (a mandarin orange tree) on the right.

sen.j: 紫宸殿の背後西側にあり、東を正面とした建物。
sen.e: Behind and to the west side of the Shishinden lies the Seiryoden, facing east.
Behind and to the west side of the Shishinden lies the Seiryoden, facing east.
Behind and to the west side of the Shishinden lies the Seiryoden, facing east.

sen.j: 入母屋造、桧皮葺の寝殿造の建物で、建具に蔀戸（しとみど）を使う点などは紫宸殿と共通する。
sen.e: The Seiryoden is the Shinden zukuri style architecture with a Irimoya zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof and the use of latticed shutters as door fittings is common to the Shishinden.
The Seiryoden is the Shinden zukuri style architecture with an Irimoya zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof, and the use of latticed shutters as door fittings is similar to the Shishinden.
The Seiryoden is the Shinden zukuri style architecture with an Irimoya zukuri style and Hiwadabuki style roof, and the use of latticed shutters as door fittings is similar to the Shishinden.

sen.j: 本来は天皇の居所兼執務所であったが、天皇が常御殿に居住するようになってからは、清涼殿も儀式の場として使われるようになっている。
sen.e: Originally, the Seiryoden was a residence and an office of the Emperor, but after the Emperor resided in the Tsunegoten, it was also used as a ceremonial hall.
Originally, the Seiryoden was a residence and an office of the Emperor but it was used as a ceremonial hall after the Emperor's residence moved to the Tsunegoten,.
Originally, the Seiryoden was a residence and an office of the Emperor but it was used as a ceremonial hall after the Emperor's residence moved to the Tsunegoten.

sen.j: 本来、居住の場であった名残で、建物内は紫宸殿よりは細かく仕切られている。
sen.e: As originally being a place of residence, inside the building is much partitioned than in the Shishinden.
Inside the building is more partitioned than in the Shishinden, a reminder that this palace was originally used a residence.
Inside the building is more partitioned than in the Shishinden, a reminder that this palace was originally used a residence.

sen.j: 中央の母屋には天皇の休憩所である御帳台（みちょうだい）がある。
sen.e: The Seiryoden has Moya in the center and Michodai inside of it, an area where the Emperor would rest.
The Seiryoden has Moya in the center and Michodai inside of it, an area where the Emperor would rest.
The Seiryoden has Moya in the center and Michodai inside of it, an area where the Emperor would rest.

sen.j: その手前（東側）には2枚の畳を敷いた「昼御座」（ひのおまし）がある。
sen.e: In front of this (the east side) lies "Hi no Omashi," an area of two tatamis.
In front of this (the east side) lies "Hi no Omashi," an area of two tatamis.
In front of this (the east side) lies "Hi no Omashi," an area of two tatamis.

sen.j: ここは天皇の公式の執務場所である。
sen.e: This was used as an office for the Emperor to conduct official affairs.
This was used as an office for the Emperor to conduct official affairs.
This was used as an office for the Emperor to conduct official affairs.

sen.j: 母屋の北側（建物正面から見て右側）には四方を壁で囲われた「夜御殿」（よんのおとど）がある。
sen.e: On the north side of the Moya (i.e., on the right side viewed from the front of the building) is "Yon no Otodo" surrounded by walls.
sen.cmt: terms欄の/ imperial sleeping quartersを削除
sen.e: On the north side of the Moya (i.e., on the right side viewed from the front of the building) is "Yon no Otodo" surrounded by walls.
On the north side of the Moya (i.e., on the right side viewed from the front of the building) is "Yon no Otodo" surrounded by walls.

sen.j: これは天皇の寝室であるが、天皇の居所が常御殿に移ってからは形式的な存在になっていた。
sen.e: This was used as a sleeping room for the Emepror, but later became a room in form after the Emperor's residence was moved to Tsunegoten.
This was used as a sleeping room for the Emperor, but later became a room only in form after the Emperor's residence was moved to Tsunegoten.
This was used as a sleeping room for the Emperor, but later became a room only in form after the Emperor's residence was moved to Tsunegoten.

sen.j: この他に西側（裏側）には鬼の間、台盤所（だいばんどころ）、朝餉の間（あさがれいのま）、御手水の間（おちょうずのま）、御湯殿があり、南側には殿上の間がある。
sen.e: On the west side (i.e., behind) are Oni-no-ma, Daibandokoro (kitchen), Asagarei-no-ma (Emperor's room for eating breakfast), Ochozu-no-ma (Emperor's morning purification room), and Oyudono (Emperor's bathroom), while on the south side is Tenjo-no-ma (courtier's room).

On the west side (i.e., behind) are Oni-no-ma, Daibandokoro (kitchen), Asagarei-no-ma (Emperor's room for eating breakfast), Ochozu-no-ma (Emperor's morning purification room), and Oyudono (Emperor's bathroom), while on the south side is Tenjo-no-ma (courtier's room).

On the west side (i.e., behind) are Oni-no-ma, Daibandokoro (kitchen), Asagarei-no-ma (Emperor's room for eating breakfast), Ochozu-no-ma (Emperor's morning purification room), and Oyudono (Emperor's bathroom), while on the south side is Tenjo-no-ma (courtier's room).

sen.j: これらの部屋の障壁画は宮廷絵師の土佐派が担当している。
sen.e: These rooms have paintings on the wall by Tosa school, the official painters at the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: terms欄のShohekigaを削除。paintings on the wall に書き換え。宮廷をImperial Palaceに書き換え。
sen.e: These rooms have paintings on the wall by Tosa school, the official painters at the Imperial Palace.
These rooms have paintings on the wall by Tosa school, the official painters at the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: また、建物正面の庭には「漢竹」（かわたけ）、「呉竹」（くれたけ）が植えられている。
sen.e: In the garden in front of the front of the building, Kawatake Bamboo and Kuretake Bamboo are planted.
In the garden in front of the front of the building, Kawatake Bamboo and Kuretake Bamboo are planted.
In the garden in front of the front of the building, Kawatake Bamboo and Kuretake Bamboo are planted.
